speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today the Federal Open Market Committee kept interest rates near zero and maintained our asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and on our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to support the economy until the recovery is complete.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Progress in vaccinations and unprecedented fiscal policy actions are also providing strong support to the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indicators of economic activity and employment have continued to strengthen, and real GDP this year appears to be on track to post its fastest rate of increase in decades.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Much of this rapid growth reflects the continued bounceback in activity from depressed levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The sectors most adversely affected by the pandemic have shown improvement but have not fully recovered.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending is rising at an especially rapid pace, boosted by the ongoing reopening of the economy and ongoing policy support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The housing sector remains very strong, and business investment is increasing at a solid pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In some industries, near-term supply constraints are restraining activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These constraints are particularly acute in the motor vehicle industry, where worldwide shortages of semiconductors have sharply curtailed production so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, conditions in the labor market have continued to improve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Demand for labor is very strong, and employment rose 850,000 in June, with the July 28, 2021 leisure and hospitality sector continuing to post notable gains.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, the labor market has Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a ways to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate in June—in June was 5.9 percent, and this figure understates the shortfall in employment, particularly as participation in the labor market has not moved up from the low rates that have prevailed for most of the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Factors related to the pandemic, such as caregiving needs, ongoing fears of the virus, and unemployment insurance payments, appear to be weighing on employment growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These factors should wane in coming months, leading to strong gains in employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on lower-wage workers in the service sector and on African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has increased notably and will likely remain elevated in coming months before moderating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the economy continues to reopen and spending rebounds, we are seeing upward pressure on prices, particularly because supply bottlenecks in some sectors have limited how quickly production can respond in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These bottleneck effects have been larger than anticipated, but as these transitory supply effects abate, inflation is expected to drop back toward our longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very low readings from early in the pandemic as well as the pass-through of past increases in oil prices to consumer energy prices also contribute to the increase, although these base effects and energy effects are receding.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The process of reopening the economy is unprecedented, as was the shutdown at the onset of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the reopening continues, bottlenecks, hiring difficulties, and other constraints could continue to limit how quickly supply can adjust, raising the possibility that July 28, 2021 inflation could turn out to be higher and more persistent than we expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our new framework for Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL monetary policy emphasizes the importance of having well-anchored inflation expectations, both to, to foster price stability and to enhance our ability to promote our broad-based and inclusive maximum-employment goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indicators of long-term inflation expectations appear broadly consistent with our longer-run inflation goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we saw signs that the path of inflation or longer-term inflation expectations were moving materially and persistently beyond levels consistent with our goal, we’d be prepared to adjust the stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The effects of the pandemic on the economy have continued to diminish, but risks to the economic outlook remain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Progress on vaccinations has limited the spread of COVID-19.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, the pace of vaccinations has slowed, and the Delta strain of the virus is spreading quickly in some areas.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Continued progress on vaccinations would support a return to more normal economic conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s policy actions have been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the Committee reiterated in today’s policy statement, with inflation having run persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect that it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions July 28, 2021 have reached level—levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are continuing to—continuing to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency MBS by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our asset purchases have been a critical tool.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They helped preserve financial stability and market functioning early in the pandemic and since then have helped foster accommodative financial conditions to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At our meeting that concluded earlier today, the Committee continued to discuss the progress made toward our—toward our goals since the Committee adopted its asset purchase guidance last December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also reviewed some considerations around how our asset purchases might be adjusted, including their pace and composition, once economic conditions warrant a change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants expect that the economy will continue to move toward our standard of “substantial further progress.” In coming meetings, the Committee will again assess the economy’s progress toward our goals, and the timing of any change in the pace of our asset purchases will depend on the incoming data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we’ve said, we will provide advance notice before making any changes to our purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On a final note, we announced the establishment of two standing repo facilities, a domestic one for primary dealers and additional banks and another for foreign and international monetary authorities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These facilities will serve as backstops in money markets to support the effective implementation of monetary policy and smooth market functioning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to support the economy for as long as it takes to complete the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So more detail on substantial further progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let’s talk about the maximum-employment part of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you know, with maximum employment—unlike with, with price stability, where we can target a number of 2 percent on average—with maximum employment, there isn’t a single number that we can target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That the—we monitor a broad range of, of, of data about different aspects of the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s unemployment, unemployment among different, different age groups, and such.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s all kinds of flow data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we look at all of it to try to arrive at a picture of what—of what is maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there isn’t—I can’t give you a, a, a set of numbers—for example, a numerical threshold like we used for a time back in 2012, I guess it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We didn’t do that here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we said was substantial further progress toward our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what we said was, we would keep, July 28, 2021 effectively, we’d—we would give advance warning as we—and, and, you know, more and more Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL clarity—as, as we move forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we’re going to try to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d say we have some ground to cover on, on the labor market side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’re, we’re some way away from, from having had substantial further progress with, with max—toward the maximum-employment goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would want to see some strong job numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and that’s, that’s kind of the idea.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So inflation is running well above our 2 percent objective and has been for a few months and is expected to run up certainly above our objective for a few months before we believe it’ll, it’ll move back down toward our objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question whether we’ve met that objective formally is really one for the Committee to make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t—I can’t do that by myself.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s clear that, at this time, inflation is actually running above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, again, has been and will be, at least we expect it will, in coming months before returning down toward our target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can hear you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, we’re, we’re in a process now where what we said is that as—at this meeting and in coming meetings, we’re going to be continuing to assess the economy’s progress toward our goals and give advance notice.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be—try to provide additional clarity about our thinking, both in the—in the postmeeting statement and in the minutes and in the public comments that people make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, our, our approach here has been to be as transparent as we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not reached substantial further progress yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re not there, and we see our ways as having some—we see ourselves as having some ground to cover to get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what I would say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of—in terms of, of COVID and the Delta strain, I’ll say a couple things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, it will have significant health consequences for many.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need to keep that in mind before we start—before we mention and move to the economic questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a—rising cases in, in a number of parts of the country, and some forecasts are for them to rise quite significantly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’ve seen, though, is with successive waves of, of COVID over the past year and some months now, there has tended to be less economic—less in the way of economic implications from each wave.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will see whether that is the case with the Delta variety.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s, you know, it’s a—it’s certainly a—not an unreasonable expectation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it, it certainly is plausible if people would pull back from some activities because of the risk of infection.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Dining out, traveling, schools might—some schools might not reopen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We may just—we may see economic effects from some of that, or it might weigh on, on the return to July 28, 2021 the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some people might choose—again, we, we don’t have a strong sense of how Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that might work out, so we’ll just be monitoring it—monitoring it carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, that would, again, be a question for the Committee.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—what the guidance is for liftoff, we had to have labor market conditions consistent with full employment, inflation at 2 percent and on track to run—to run moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It—because we’re really—we’re looking at, at tapering asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re clearly a ways away from considering raising interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not something that, that is on our radar screen right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so when we get to that question, when we start to get to the question of, of liftoff, which, which we are not at all at now or near now, that’s when we’ll ask that question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is when that, that will become a real question for us.

sentence: Jeanna, I’m sorry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s an—it’s an important feature of this recovery is how uneven it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, in many cases, that’s related to the fact that some countries have had little in the way of access to, to vaccines.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so they’re seeing significant outbreaks, and it’s weighing on economic activity, whereas other countries—such as the United States, in particular—are having a very strong rebound.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and now Europe is having a stronger rebound as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a feature of our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In, in a couple of ways, potentially.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One just is that, in general, economies—and through financial markets and through trade—are, are deeply interconnected now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so a stronger global economy will lead to more U.S. exports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, that’ll help economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To the extent the global economy is weak and the United States is strong, it’ll—we’ll wind up, you know, we’ll wind up exporting some of our demand through, through imports rather than having, having a lot of exports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another way, though, is more on the risk side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is, as long as COVID is running loose out there, as long as there’s time and space for the development of new strains, no one’s July 28, 2021 really finally safe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These, these strains—there’s no reason they just can’t keep coming and one, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL you know, one more powerful than the next.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s, that’s, that’s certainly a plausible outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, as, as vaccinations rise, we can nonetheless get back to our economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, it, it is both the right thing to do and, and very much in our interest to make sure that vaccination happens broadly around the world, just for that reason.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d be glad to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look, again, if you look at the, the most recent inflation report, what you see is that it came in significantly higher than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But essentially all of the overshoot can be tied to a handful of categories.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t the kind of inflation that’s spread broadly across the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s new, used, and rental cars.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s airplane tickets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hotels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s a couple of other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And each of those has a story attached to it that is—that is really about the reopening of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at that, and we think that those are temporary things because the, the supply side will respond.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy will adapt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have a very adaptive, adaptable, flexible economy and labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s a real—a real asset that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we think that inflation should move down over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, we don’t have any—much confidence, let’s say, in the timing of that or the size of the effects in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, in the near term, that July 28, 2021 the, the, the risks to inflation are probably to the upside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I, I have some confidence in the—in Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the medium term, that inflation will move back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, it’s hard to say when that will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I, I will say, though, that, you know, we—inflation is half of our mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is half of our mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we were to see inflation moving up to levels persistently that were—that were above, significantly, materially above our goal and particularly if inflation expectations were to move up, we would use our tools to guide inflation back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we won’t have an extended period of, of high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that, that some of it will, will fall away naturally as the process of reopening the economy moves through.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it could take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In any case, we will use our tools over time as appropriate to make sure that we do have inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so in terms of what’s been happening in bond markets, I don’t think there’s a real consensus on, on what explains the moves between the last meeting and this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen the long-term yields go down significantly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of it is a fall in real yields, which may have been connected to—some speculate—connected to sentiment around the, the spread of the Delta variant and concern about growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was also some decline in inflation compensation, which has significantly reversed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there, there are also so-called technical factors, which is where you put things that you can’t quite explain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I, I don’t see in any of that that there is really anything that challenges the July 28, 2021 credibility of our framework, if, if that’s really your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to achieving Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL 2 percent average inflation over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we said was that, in particular, when we see a very strong labor market, high levels of employment, low levels of unemployment, that won’t be enough for us to raise interest rates until we see some inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, what we have today is kind of the opposite.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve got, you know, 7 or 8 million people, fewer people, at work than were at work before the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, you know, we’re, we’re a ways away from full maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we have high inflation, so it’s kind of the opposite case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have to—we have to deal with that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Any central bank has to deal with that by looking at the inflation and asking whether it is broad based and likely to be persistent and, and, and whether inflation expectations are implicated in a way that, that could cause them to rise.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re monitoring that very carefully, and we’re prepared to use our tools as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, I think our—I think our framework is pretty well understood.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I think the real test of it will be down the road when it’s time to think about raising interest rates and, and how we assess, assess that set of issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a—there’s a part in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and, and Monetary Policy Strategy, which, Rich, I’m sure—I’m sure you’re familiar with, which, which talks about that case in which the two goals are in tension.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Most of the time, if you have high inflation, you also have high employment—they, they tend to go together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a situation where they’re temporarily in different directions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not at full employment, but we are having high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We feel like we’re going to be making good progress over the next—over the course of the next year, couple of years, really, toward maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a very strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the number of job openings compared to the number of unemployed, it’s—we’re, we’re clearly on a path to a very strong labor market with high participation, low unemployment, high employment, wages moving up across the spectrum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, that’s, that’s the path that we’re on, and, and it shouldn’t take that long in macroeconomic time to get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s what I think is, is really the likely case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, it’s not—it’s not timely for us to be thinking about, about raising interest rates right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re doing is, we’re, we’re looking at our asset purchases and judging what is right for the economy and judging how we—how close we are to substantial further progress and then—and then tapering after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question you asked about, would we raise rates if we hadn’t finished cutting—hadn’t finished the taper, hypothetical question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’d, we’d face the circumstance at the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We could always just—you know, one thing one could do would be to just cut asset purchases all the way to zero if you wanted to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s, it’s, it’s just hard to—it’s hard to answer what you would do without knowing a lot more about the situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ideally, you wouldn’t be still buying assets and raising rates because, of course, you’re adding July 28, 2021 accommodation by buying and, and removing accommodation by raising rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that wouldn’t Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL be ideal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a—it’s a really unusual situation to have—to have the ratio of vacancies to unemployed be this high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think there are a number of things at work there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Maybe the place to start is, is just to say that this is now not so much about people going back to their old jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s about finding a new job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a time-intensive, labor-intensive process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there may be a bit of a speed limit on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There, there’s research that suggests that there is a speed limit on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s not like you can have millions of people at the beginning of the recovery going back in a single month because they’re just going back to their old job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is about job selection, things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There may also be some factors that are—that are holding people back, and that’s—this is what surveys say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are people who, who are reluctant to go back to work because they still feel exposed to COVID.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These could be jobs where, where there was a lot of, of interaction with the public and where perhaps there’s a family member who’s vulnerable or for whatever reason.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s also caretakers who are—where, where schools are not fully open and parents are at home or taking care of, of, of older people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there’s also been very generous July 28, 2021 unemployment benefits, which are now rolling off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ll be—they’ll be fully rolled off in a Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL couple of months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And all of those factors should, should wane.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we think we should see, because of that, we should see strong job creation moving forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, ultimately, it’s unusual to see aspects like the job openings number in a context where there are that many unemployed people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That many job openings would typically suggest a tight labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we hear from businesses all over the country that it’s very hard to hire people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that may be because people, people are shopping carefully for their next job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you remember the, the summer wave last year of COVID, which was largely southern and western states, the economy just performed much better July 28, 2021 than anyone expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we, we were coming off the spring wave, where there were a Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL lot of shutdowns.

sentence: And then this big second wave hit, and I think the natural thing to do is to expect that, that it would have a real impact on the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People—what’s happened is, first of all, many people are vaccinated.

sentence: Secondly, we’ve kind of learned to live with it.

sentence: You know, of course, the big wave we had last winter did have significant employment effects, particularly in, you know, hospitality and leisure and other entertainment—other, other areas with a lot of direct contact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: Well, I think strong capital requirements are essential for banks, particularly for the largest banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So with inflation, as I mentioned, we’re, we look not just at the headline number, but we look at all the components that go into the calculation of inflation.
